title: 107_s3032
content: AMENDMENTS TO THE MICROENTERPRISE FOR SELF-RELIANCE ACT OF 2000. Amendment to the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000 includes changing terminology to "microenterprise households", updating policy to focus on the "very poor", and ensuring that 50% of assistance targets the very poor. The amendment to the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act of 2000 includes redefining "microentrepreneurs" to include their households and defining "very poor" as individuals living below the poverty line or on less than $1 per day. AMENDMENTS TO THE MICRO- AND SMALL ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT CREDITS PROGRAM UNDER THE FOREIGN ASSISTANCE ACT OF 1961. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to focus on increasing access to financial services and developing microenterprises. This includes providing loans, guarantees, and training programs for microfinance institutions to support poor and low-income households. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to focus on increasing access to financial services for microenterprise households. This includes providing training programs for clients to improve their financial literacy and manage their enterprises effectively. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to prioritize programs for microenterprise households, with funding available for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. Section 108 of the Act is updated to reflect these changes. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to prioritize microenterprise development credits. Amendments are made to the microenterprise development grant assistance program for fiscal years 2001 through 2004. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to prioritize microenterprise development by facilitating access to financial services and providing assistance to developing countries. This includes programs offering credit, savings, training, technical assistance, and business development services. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to prioritize microenterprise development by facilitating access to financial services for rural and urban poor populations in developing countries. This includes programs offering credit, savings, training, technical assistance, and business development services. Amendments include changing terminology from "entrepreneurs" to "clients" and from "microfinance" to "microenterprise." The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to prioritize microenterprise development by facilitating access to financial services for rural and urban poor populations in developing countries. This includes programs offering credit, savings, training, technical assistance, and business development services. Amendments include changing terminology from "entrepreneurs" to "clients" and from "microfinance" to "microenterprise." Additionally, amendments involve the adoption of poverty assessment tools to identify the very poor and ensure they receive necessary microenterprise loans, savings, and assistance. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development is tasked with developing and certifying poverty measurement methods for application in these programs. The United States Agency for International Development will develop low-cost methods for partner institutions to assess poverty levels of clients, field-test these methods, and certify at least two poverty measurement methods by October 1, 2004. The Administrator will certify at least two approved methods for measuring poverty levels of microenterprise clients for assistance under the Act. Organizations must use a certified method starting from October 1, 2005. Assistance levels are set at $175,000,000 for fiscal year 2003 and $200,000,000 for fiscal year 2004. Definitions under the Act are also amended. The term 'very poor' is defined as individuals living below the poverty line or on less than $1 per day. SEC. 4. REPORT TO CONGRESS. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development must submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2005, documenting the poverty assessment procedures with partners. Starting from fiscal year 2006, annual reports must address compliance with the Microenterprise for Self-Reliance Act by detailing resource allocation to the very poor based on certified methods. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development must submit a report to Congress documenting poverty assessment procedures with partners and the number of very poor reached based on certified methods.
